title: Research
text:
Research Interests
My primary research interests is in infinite groups, their actions on spaces and their interplay with dynamical systems.
Currently, I have been particularly interested in generalisations of the Higman-Thompson groups and their connections to shift dynamical systems.
I am also interested in connections between group theory and theoretical computer science. In particular, decision problems in groups, cellular automata and groups generated by automata.

title: Dr Feyishayo Olukoya  PhD, MMath, FHEA
text:
About me
I am a research fellow at the University of St Andrews and holder of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council Fellowship “The Higman-Thompson groups, their generalisations, and automorphisms of shift spaces” that investigates the interplay between (generalisations) of the Higman-Thompson groups and shift dynamical systems.
In December 2018, I obtained my PhD in pure mathematics at the University of St Andrews. This was funded by the Carnegie Trust for the Universities of Scotland and was supervised by of Dr. Collin Bleak and Dr. Martyn Quick. Since then I have been a postdoctoral research fellow working in geometric and combinatorial group theory at the Institute of Mathematics at the University of Aberdeen (2018-2020); an LMS Early Career Fellow and then an Associate Lecturer in the School of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of St Andrews (2020-2022). Over the course of the latter position, I attained Fellowship of the Higher Education Academy and while at the University of Aberdeen, I was one of only two members of staff in the Institute of Mathematics, nominated for a teaching excellence award.
Immediately prior to my current role, I held a lectureship in pure mathematics at Keele University

title: Outreach
text:
“You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view. Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it”

– Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird
I am keen to promote mathematics amongst underrepresented groups in STEM. I have an incipient YouTube channel where I discuss various mathematics (and related) topics emphasising, where possible, a non-western point of view. I hope also to include more personal content about my own mathematics journey
I am happy to speak about this to high school and primary school students. If you would like to get in touch, then please do send me an email at feyisayo.olukoya@gmail.com.

title: Outreach
text:
Activities
I, together with a colleague at St Andrews, recently sponsored, a summer project as part of a scheme to help undergraduate students further enhance their graduate attributes. The students were tasked with producing resources to help a willing sceptic learn more about why the mathematics curriculum needs to be decolonised, and what they can do about it
The students did a fantastic job on this and here is a link to their final output.
